Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CHS: Scaling Up Online Peer Tutoring of Computer Programming

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop innovative software to broaden access to free one-on-one tutoring, starting in the domain of computer programming, which is crucial for many kinds of 21st-century jobs. Learning is one of the most important and fundamental lifelong endeavors. A well-educated public is crucial for maintaining a healthy, prosperous, and innovative society. Regardless of subject, one-on-one tutoring is the most personal and effective way to learn. Although recent efforts such as MOOCs (Massive Open Online Courses) are scaling up access to lectures and other educational materials, it is hard to scale up one-on-one tutoring to online settings because there are far more learners in the world than qualified expert tutors. Access to free online tutors will especially benefit lower-income learners, who are more likely to be from rural areas or underrepresented minority groups.

The technical objective of this project is to investigate how to scale up peer tutoring of computer programming through user interfaces and algorithms for matching learners with tutors, hosting tutoring sessions within real-time code visualizations, and reviewing archived sessions. The central idea is to draw from the large pool of learners concurrently accessing online educational resources to serve as peer tutors for one another. Although peers lack the deep expertise of experts, many are effective tutors since they recently learned the material and can empathize better with learners. This project will build upon Online Python Tutor, a Web-based educational tool that the researcher created to visualize the execution of computer code, now one of the most popular websites for learning programming in the Python language. This project's specific aims are to build a peer tutoring system atop the Online Python Tutor website and to use it to study online peer tutoring interactions. The system has two main components: 1.) PythonLive is a real-time tutoring interface for computer programming that enables multiple users to concurrently write, execute, visualize, and chat about code, a single tutor to effectively handle multiple simultaneous tutees, and offline learning by reviewing archived tutoring sessions. 2.) TutorMatch is an interface that uses crowdsourcing and machine learning to connect learners with appropriately-skilled peer tutors in real-time. In sum, this research will contribute new software-based techniques to facilitate peer tutoring of computer programming, which draws upon and contributes to the fields of human-computer interaction, social computing, and computer-supported cooperative learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One-on-one tutoring is one of the most personal and effective ways to learn. Although recent efforts such as MOOCs (Massive Open Online Courses) are scaling up access to video lectures and other educational materials, it is hard to scale up live one-on-one tutoring to online settings because there are far more learners in the world than qualified expert tutors. One way to overcome this limitation is to draw from the large pool of learners concurrently accessing online educational resources to serve as peer tutors for one another.

This project has created interactive online systems for facilitating one-on-one peer tutoring for the domain of computer programming, hosted on a website (Python Tutor - www.pythontutor.com) with hundreds of learners who are using it at any given point in time. Why computer programming? Because programming is now a vital skill for students in many fields to learn, which can lead to jobs in sectors ranging from science to technology to public policy. This project has resulted in widely-deployed peer tutoring systems that are available for the public to use for free at the PI's Python Tutor educational website (www.pythontutor.com). In addition, this project has produced four academic research papers, accompanying summary blog posts for public consumption, and training of four graduate students in relevant fields.

In terms of intellectual merits, this project has contributed new software-based techniques to facilitate peer tutoring of computer programming, which has led to four research publications in the field of human-computer interaction (HCI). This contribution is significant because it advances the state of knowledge about how to use technology to bring one-on-one tutoring, which has traditionally been an intimate face-to-face interaction, into a large-scale anonymous online setting. In particular, this research 1) introduced best-practice design patterns for building real-time human tutoring systems at scale and deploying to hundreds of thousands of learners, 2) made scientific discoveries about what leads to effective online tutoring interactions, and 3) generated a corpus of anonymized tutoring sessions to enable researchers to study peer tutoring in online settings.

In terms of broader societal impacts, computer programming is a crucial skill for many kinds of 21st-century jobs and for growing a digitally literate citizenship. This project's outcomes served to broaden participation in learning programming by providing free tutoring services on a popular website, Python Tutor, which already reaches millions of people around the world. Access to free tutors especially benefits lower-income learners, who are more likely to be from rural areas or underrepresented minority groups. This project has also had direct impacts on training the next generation of students who aspire to become computer programmers, and increasingly, data scientists (a fast­-growing job title in recent years) who need to learn programming to analyze data. The free online tutoring provided by this project on the PI's Python Tutor online platform has already helped tens of thousands of learners receive free tutoring, which helps their professional development toward future STEM careers.
